summary: This is a July 22, 2020 letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Sarah Netburn, requesting that all filings in a miscellaneous case related to a grand jury investigation remain under seal. The government argues that unsealing would jeopardize the ongoing investigation, which has resulted in indictments against Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, and that grand jury secrecy must be maintained.

persons.name: Sarah Netburn
persons.context: Presiding judge to whom the government's letter is addressed, regarding the sealing of materials in a miscellaneous case related to the grand jury investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as a subject against whom charges have been brought in connection with the ongoing grand jury investigation.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Referenced as a defendant in a recently filed criminal case (United States v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN)), which is an outcome of the ongoing grand jury investigation.

connections.description: Both are named as subjects/defendants in charges brought as a result of the same ongoing grand jury investigation, as referenced in the government's letter.

events.title: Government's Sealing Request Filed
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office files a letter with Judge Netburn requesting that all filings in a miscellaneous case related to a grand jury investigation remain under seal.

events.title: Court Order on Sealing
events.description: Judge Netburn issues an order directing the government to state its position on whether filings in the miscellaneous case should remain under seal.

events.title: New Charges Against Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The government notes that the ongoing grand jury investigation resulted in new charges being brought against Ghislaine Maxwell this month (United States v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN)).

events.title: Government's Grand Jury Application
events.description: The government filed an application in connection with the then-pending grand jury investigation, which is the subject of the miscellaneous case.

locations: United States Courthouse, New York, New York 10007
The Silvio J. Moto Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office is actively opposing the unsealing of materials in a miscellaneous case, arguing it is necessary to protect an ongoing grand jury investigation.
The grand jury investigation has resulted in unsealed indictments, including against Jeffrey Epstein and, recently, Ghislaine Maxwell (United States v. Maxwell).
The government states the investigation remains active and ongoing, with details such as certain subjects, offenses, and witness/victim identities not publicly known.
The government intends to provide defendant Ghislaine Maxwell with relevant materials from the sealed cases as part of discovery, but will seek a protective order to maintain secrecy.
The government proposes a follow-up in approximately 180 days to update the court on its sealing position.
